turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: How did this... how did I let this happen?

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: You couldn't have known.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I should have known... once I would have... I used to be wary... and today I watched my son killed before my eyes... your sister civilized me and I damn myself for having let her...

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Thomas is dead but you've done nothing for which you should be ashamed.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I've done nothing and for that I am ashamed.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: If you go, I'll care for them as if they were my own.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I'll leave in the morning with Gabriel.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: I said, I'm not my sister.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I know that.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Of course, I do.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Very well, then.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Goodbye, Charlotte.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Goodbye.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Two pounds, fourteen ounces.

turns.speaker: CHARLOTTE
turns.text: Lovely.

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: You're surrendering.

turns.speaker: CONTINENTAL SERGEANT
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: What unit?

turns.speaker: CONTINENTAL SERGEANT
turns.text: First Virginia Regulars under Colonel Hamilton.

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: Who cared for your wounds?

turns.speaker: CONTINENTAL SERGEANT
turns.text: We did.

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: With a lace table cloth?

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: My boys... my boys... you seem to have been well fed.  Thank you for that, Colonel.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: My pleasure, sir.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Please forgive me for keeping you waiting.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Apology accepted.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Thank you, Colonel... I'm afraid I don't know your name.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Colonel will do.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: As you wish.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Shall we proceed?

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Let us.  Unless you object, I would like to deem this meeting a formal negotiation and, as such, there are certain customary practices. Perhaps I could explain them to you...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I'm familiar with how a formal negotiation is handled.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I served in His Majesty's army in the French and Indian War.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Oh.  Very well, then.  Would you, as the initiating party, like to begin?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Unless you would like to claim aggrieved status.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: You are familiar with how these things are done.  In fact, I would like to claim aggrieved status.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Very well, proceed, sir.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: First, you have in your possession certain belongings of mine, including clothing, private papers, furniture and personal effects of a non-military nature which I would like to have returned to me.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I will do so as soon as possible.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Please accept my apology for not having done so sooner.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Apology accepted.  Now, on the matter of the specific targeting of officers during engagements, this is absolutely unacceptable.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: That one is a bit more difficult.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Certainly you must know that in civilized warfare, officers in the field must not be accorded inappropriate levels of hostile attention.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: And what are inappropriate levels of hostile attention?

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Colonel, imagine the utter chaos that would result from un-led armies having at each other.  There must be gentlemen in command to lead and, when appropriate, restrain their men.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Restrain them from the targeting of civilians, including women and children?

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: That is a separate issue.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I consider them linked.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: I beg to differ.  One is a command decision on your part.  The other represents nothing more than the occasional over-exuberance of field officers attempting to carry out their duty in difficult circumstances.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: As long as your soldiers attack civilians, I will order the shooting of your officers at the outset of every engagement.  And my men are excellent marksmen.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Very well, let us move on to...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Prisoner exchange.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You have eighteen of my men.  I want them back.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: I do have eighteen criminals under sentence of death, but I hold no prisoners-of-war.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: If that's your position, then eighteen of your officers will die. Nineteen, if you hang me with my men.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: What officers?

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Their names, ranks and posts?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: They refused to give me their names. Their ranks are nine lieutenants, five captains, three majors and one fat colonel who called me a cheeky fellow.  Their posts?  We picked them up here-and-there last night.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: My harrier.  Join us, Colonel.

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: Sir.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Colonel Tarleton, you deal with these damned rebels.

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: It seems our Swamp Fox wants to have a formal parley.

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: Are you going to meet with him?

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Most certainly.  Arrange it.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: If I fail, you fail.

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: Perhaps.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: And if I triumph, you triumph.

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: Probably.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: How can we end this madness?

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: Difficult, sir.  This is, as you pointed out, a civil war.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Civility is a secondary virtue.  It is superseded by duty.

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: I understand, sir.

turns.speaker: CORNWALLIS
turns.text: Do you see that, Colonel?

turns.speaker: TARLETON
turns.text: Unless I'm dreaming, I think I see irregulars at their center.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Father, a post rider came from Charleston.  You have a letter inside.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Thank you.  How's the spotted one's milk?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: The New York and Rhode Island assemblies have been dissolved...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: The middle colonies?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Rioting both sides of the bay, in Chestertown they burned the Customs House and tar-and-feathered the Customs Agent.  He died of burns. In Wilmington they killed a Royal Magistrate and two Redcoats.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Anything about the convention in Philadelphia?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Poor Richard says they'll make a Declaration of Independence by July.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: What news?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: The British army is barricaded in Boston.  Harry Lee, is here from Virginia, recruiting for a Continental Army.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Is that why the Assembly was convened?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Yes.  He seeks a levy of troops and money.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: And the Governor?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: He vowed that if the Assembly votes a single shilling to Lee, he'll dissolve the body.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Which would force our delegates in Philadelphia to vote for independence.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Father, I've lost respect for you. I thought you were a man of principle.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: When you have children, I hope you'll understand.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: When I have children, I hope I don't hide behind them.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Do you intend to enlist without my permission?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Have you seen any Redcoats?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Not yet.  What happened?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: I have to get these dispatches to Hillsboro.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You're in no condition to ride.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: I have no choice, I...

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Father...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: It's already over.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: What now, sir?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: We put out the word.  We'll start along the south side of the Santee...

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: We'd cover more ground if we split up.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: It's safer if we stay together.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Colonel, I didn't request this transfer because you're my father. I requested it because I believe in this cause and this is where I can do the most good.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: I've been doing this for two years. I'm the best scout in the Continental Army, the best horseman, the best shot, the best scavenger and I know every deer path and swamp trail between here and Charleston.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Is that so?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Yes, sir.  My father taught me.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Did your father teach you humility?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: He tried.  It didn't take.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Alright, Corporal, you take Bennington, Harrisville, Acworth and the farms along Black Swamp.  I'll take the north side of the river. We'll meet at Snow's Island.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: And, Corporal...  ... be careful.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Yes...  ... father.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Is it?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: If you're here only for revenge, you're doing a disservice to him as well as yourself.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: How old are you?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: You know how old I am.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: God help us all when you're forty.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Less than a mile.  Forty-one wagons, a company of Redcoat infantry, horses at the rear.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Flanking riders?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: I didn't see any.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: These four wagons must be his.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: And the dogs, too, I'll wager.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Lord Cornwallis is brilliant.  His weakness is that he knows it.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Father?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Pride is his weakness.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Gabriel?  Are you asleep?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: We're low on salt.  I should go to Pembroke and get some.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Fourteen dead, eleven wounded, eighteen captured.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I should have killed him when I had the chance?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: When was that?  In the swamp at the expense of your men?  Or when he killed Thomas at the expense of your family?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Or perhaps tomorrow at the expense of our cause.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Stay the course... your mother used to say that to me when I'd get drunk or lose my temper.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: She'd say it to me when I picked on Thomas or Nathan.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You learned her lessons better than I.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: She got me at a more impressionable age.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: She spoke?  Susan spoke?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Full sentences.  As if she had been speaking all along.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I don't believe it... and I wasn't there for it...

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: She said... she loves you and misses you but she understands why you can't be there with her.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: She said that?  Oh, my Lord, she said that?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Father, there's something else I need to talk to you about.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Come with me.  I'll tell you when we get there.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Sir, I'd like to request a furlough. Two days?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Granted.  Where are you going?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Cheraw Falls.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: It's beautiful there.  Your mother and I were there once, before you were born.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Tarleton has a list of our men, most are on it.  A regiment of dragoons is going to the homes on the list, burning them, killing whomever resists, women and children, as well.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Seven homes along the Black River so far...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Don't go in there.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Is it her?  Is Anne in there?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: She is.  Don't go in there.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Father, tell me what happened at Fort Wilderness?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You know what happened.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: No, I don't.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Everyone knows.  It's what made me a hero.  Me, Harry Lee, all of us.  I got a medal.  Men bought me drinks. They still do sometimes.  Everyone knows what happened.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Tell me what everyone doesn't know.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: And what do they know?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: That the French and Cherokees captured the fort and when you retook it, you took revenge on them for what they did during the occupation.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: That's not enough.  Tell me.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Your mother asked me the same question around the time you were born.  I was drunk and I was foolish enough to answer her.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: That's why it was four years between you and Thomas.  It took me that long to regain her respect.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: I'm not my mother.  I can't have the respect without the knowing.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: We buried them, then we went to track.  It was a cold trail and they were moving fast.  We went faster. We caught up to them at Kentucky Ford.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: We took our time with them and gave every one of them worse than they had given at the fort.  It was two weeks before they were all dead, all except two.  We put the heads on a pallet and had the two we let live take it to the French at Fort Ambercon.  The eyes, fingers and tongues we put in a basket and sent that down the Asheulot to the Cherokee.  The French stayed east of the Blue Ridge after that and the Cherokee broke their treaty with the French and stayed out of the fight.  That seemed to make a difference. The war went another year, things went better... and men bought us drinks.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: It was a different time, son.  And you're a better man than that.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: I see, do as I say, not as I do.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: If this war is about more than Thomas, it's about more than Anne, as well.  Stay the course.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: As you did at Fort Wilderness?

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: He wanted to, Susan, but he couldn't leave his men.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: He left us.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: I know he did and he's sorry.  He'll come back as soon as he can.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: There are some letters here from him.  Some are just to you.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I don't care.  I hate him.

turns.speaker: GABRIEL
turns.text: You don't hate him.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yes, I do.  I hate him and I hope he never comes back.

turns.speaker: ROBINSON
turns.text: An American nation.  Colonel Lee, with your permission?

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: ROBINSON
turns.text: Those of us who call ourselves Patriots are not seeking to give birth to an American nation, but to protect one that already exists.  It was born a hundred-and-seventy years ago at Jamestown, Virginia and has grown stronger and more mature with every generation reared and with every crop sown and harvested.  We are a nation and our rights as citizens of that nation are threatened by a tyrant three thousand miles away.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Thank you.  Were I an orator, those are the exact words I would have spoken.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Mister Robinson, I fought with Captain Marion in the French and Indian War, including the Wilderness Campaign.  We served as scouts under Washington and I have no doubts about Captain Marion's courage or competence on a battlefield. There's not a man in this room, or anywhere, for that matter, to whom I would more willingly trust my life.

turns.speaker: ROBINSON
turns.text: I stand corrected.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Nonetheless, I would like to know, Mister Marion, how... how... how...

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Captain Marion, I understood you to be a Patriot.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: It's Mister Marion.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: I understood him to be a Patriot as well.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Damn it, Francis!  How in God's name do you expect to gain independence without going to war?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Harry, Harry, Harry...

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: A long time ago...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Thirteen years...

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: That's a damn long time...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You were an Englishman then...

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: I was an American, I just didn't know it yet...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: We don't have to go to war to gain independence...

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Balderdash!

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: There are a thousand avenues, other than war, at our disposal...

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Name five hundred.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Royal petition, delegates to court, judicial redress, economic boycott, bribery...

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: That's five, keep going...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: ... time, royal succession, regicide, bribery...

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: You said bribery twice...

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Wars are not fought only by childless men.  A man must weigh his personal responsibilities against his principles.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: That's what I'm doing.  I will not fight and because I won't, I will not cast a vote that will send others to fight in my stead.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: And your principles?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I'm a parent, I don't have the luxury of principles.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: One of yours?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Gabriel.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: I recognize him now.  Is he as imprudent as his father was at his age?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: No, thank the Lord.  He's more like his mother.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: I'll see to it that he serves under me.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Green Dragoons came to my home, killed my son, Thomas.  It was Tarleton himself.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I'm sorry I wasn't here for this.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: There's nothing you could have done, Gates is a damned fool.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: We saw.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: I begged him to stay in the cover of the trees but he insisted the only way to break Cornwallis was muzzle- to-muzzle.  He spent too many years in the British army.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Where is he now?

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Last anyone saw, riding hard, northeast, his staff a hundred yards behind, trying to catch up.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Who's in command?

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: I am, I think.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: What are my orders?

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: We're a breath away from losing this war.  In the North, Washington is reeling from Valley Forge, running and hiding from Clinton and twelve thousand Redcoats.  Here in the South, Cornwallis has broken our back.  He captured over five thousand of our troops when he took Charleston and today he destroyed the only army that stood between him and New York.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: So now Cornwallis will head north, link up with Clinton and finish off Washington.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: And Patriots will start dying on the gallows instead of the battlefield.  Unless we can keep Cornwallis in the South until the French arrive.  A treaty was signed at Versailles after our victory at Saratoga.  The French are sending a fleet and ten thousand troops.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Fall, six months at the earliest.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Long time.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: The bigger problem is where, not when.  The French fleet won't sail north of the Chesapeake for fear of early storms.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: So you're going to try to keep Cornwallis in the South until then.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Not me, you.  I'm going north with every Continental regular I can find to reinforce Washington or he won't last six weeks.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You expect Cornwallis to be held here by militia?

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Not held, just slowed down.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: They're nothing but farmers and you're asking them to try to keep a tiger in their backyard.  They'd be better off letting it move on.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: They'd be better off, but the cause wouldn't be.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: How many men does Cornwallis have under his command?

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Four thousand infantry and around six hundred cavalry...  ... including the Green Dragoons under Tarleton.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: His wife was killed yesterday.  She was with child.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: I'm sorry, I didn't know.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Don't touch him.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: How many men have we seen die?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Two.  Gabriel and Thomas.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: They're gone.  And there is nothing you or I can do to bring them back. But there is something you can do to help end all this.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: It is ended.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: No.  It's not over yet.  Two days ride, Yorktown, Virginia. Washington, the French, Cornwallis and Tarleton.  It will end, one way or another.  Francis, nothing will replace your sons but helping us will justify their sacrifice.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Goodbye, Francis.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Goodbye, Harry.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: And congratulations on the birth of your son.

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Thank you.  Maybe all of this will buy him some peace.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I hope so.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Your son, what did you name him?

turns.speaker: LEE
turns.text: Robert.  Robert E. Lee.

turns.speaker: MAJOR HALBERT
turns.text: Lord Cornwallis will be with you presently.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MAJOR HALBERT
turns.text: You may, of course, keep your weapons, but I must warn you that...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I'm familiar with appropriate behavior at a military parley.

turns.speaker: MAJOR HALBERT
turns.text: Yes, quite, but you should know that...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: That will be all, Major.  I'll wait for Lord Cornwallis.

turns.speaker: MAJOR HALBERT
turns.text: Yes... you will wait.

turns.speaker: MARGARET
turns.text: How far away?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Four, five miles.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Don't worry.

turns.speaker: MARGARET
turns.text: We could go stay at Aunt Charlotte's farm.  She's to the west.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: No, there'll be skirmishers on the roads.  We're safer here.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Margaret, take William and Susan to the river shed.  Hide there.  If we're not back by dawn, go up the river to the Richardson's house. They'll take you to your Aunt Charlotte's farm.  Nathan, Samuel, and I are going to get Gabriel.

turns.speaker: MARGARET
turns.text: But what about Thomas?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Leave him.  Take care of William and Susan.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Reverend.

turns.speaker: REV. OLIVER
turns.text: I heard about your son.  I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: REV. OLIVER
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: REV. OLIVER
turns.text: For trying to impose some decency on that sort.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Don't depend on my decency.  I'm one of that sort.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: It's a good measure of a woman that she'll have her honeymoon under the stars.

turns.speaker: REV. OLIVER
turns.text: For richer, for poorer, in sickness and in health, 'til death do they part.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: How many came back?

turns.speaker: REV. OLIVER
turns.text: About a hundred and twenty.  Less than a third.

turns.speaker: REV. OLIVER
turns.text: Colonel, let us help his soul find it's place with the Almighty and...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: He looks as if he's sleeping, doesn't he?

turns.speaker: REV. OLIVER
turns.text: Yes, he does.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Gray.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Earned.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I was sorry to hear about your son.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I lost another a year ago, Thomas. He was only fifteen.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I've had no sons to lose, nor daughters.  I lose the sons of other men.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Francis, tell me about General Cornwallis.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Remember Braddock?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: That bad?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Worse.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Proud, priggish and competent.  A very bad combination in an adversary.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: If Cornwallis receives news that Clinton is coming, he'll simply hold tight and wait.  He'll fight a purely defensive battle and he'll win that.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: No, he won't.  There are two things you need to know about Cornwallis. First, he is a very proud man, He would rather risk defeat than share a victory.  If you give him what he thinks is an out, he'll take it.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: And what is the second thing?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Not yet, Thomas.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Seventeen.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: But it's already been two years and that's two more years.  The war could be over by then.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: God willing.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Put those away.

turns.speaker: THOMAS
turns.text: But father, they might come this way.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Put them away.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Father, I saw a post rider at the house.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Thank you.  Did you finish the upper field?

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Father?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Six-pounders.  Lots of them.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Father, you can't let them take him...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Quiet.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: Father... I killed those men...

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: Don't blame yourself, you did what I told you to do.

turns.speaker: NATHAN
turns.text: I'm glad I killed them... I'm glad...

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Who might you be, little Miss?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm Ellen Creed and I live at 642 Alden Lane, Dearborn, Michigan.  At least, I used to.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: And now you live on Route 9 in Ludlow, and your dad's gonna be the new doctor up to the college, I hear, and I think you're going to be just as happy as a clam here, Ellen Creed.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But where are we going, Mr. Crandall?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: You'll see soon enough, hon.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Best never to go climbing on old blowdowns like this, Ellie--sometimes they bite.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Bite?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Ayuh.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Do you know what this place is, Ellie? Oh, I know you know it's a boneyard, but a bone ain't nothing and even a whole pile of 'em don't amount to much. Do you know what a graveyard really is?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well...I guess not.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: It's a place where the dead speak, Missy.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What if you can't read what's written on there anymore?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Well, it still says some animal got laid down here after, don't it?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes--

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: They do it to honor the dead, Ellen.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Is that right, dad?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Ellie...God doesn't do things like that. I know you loved y'brother, but--

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: He can if He wants to. He can do anything, just like Inspector Gadget on TV. But I have to keep things ready for him, that's what I think. I've got his picture and I'm going to sit in his chair--

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: It's gorgeous!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Am I really gonna have my own room?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Yes, but the rope might be--

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yaay!

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Honey, Church will be fine.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But what if he dies and has to go to the Pet Sematary?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I want to fly it! Can I fly it now, mommy!

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: In a minute, hon. Let Gage finish his turn.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Paxcow says it's almost too late!

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Ellie...Ellie...what...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Paxcow says it's almost too late! We have to go back! Paxcow says it's almost too late!
